content.title: DRIL Procedure for Steal Syndrome
content.definition: Distal Revascularization-Interval Ligation (DRIL) - a surgical procedure to treat hemodialysis access-induced steal syndrome by restoring distal arterial perfusion while maintaining access function.

clinical_features.steal_syndrome: Symptomatic steal not responsive to access banding

concepts.definition: Key steps in the DRIL procedure.

clinical_features.bypass: Create bypass from proximal brachial artery to artery distal to access
clinical_features.ligation: Ligate brachial artery between access and distal anastomosis
clinical_features.conduit: Vein bypass preferred (reversed GSV or arm vein)
clinical_features.result: Distal arm perfused via bypass, access fed by proximal artery

clinical_features.reversal: Prevents retrograde flow from distal artery into access
clinical_features.augmentation: Bypass provides antegrade perfusion to distal arm
clinical_features.access_preservation: Access continues to function via proximal artery

clinical_features.alternative: Access ligation if tissue loss extensive or patient not bypass candidate
